title: 104_hr2940
content:
The Act is titled the "Deepwater Port Modernization Act" and declares its purpose and policy. The Deepwater Port Modernization Act aims to update and improve regulations for deepwater ports, ensuring they are not overly burdensome compared to other oil transportation modes. It also aims to promote competition, innovation, flexibility, and efficiency by reducing unnecessary federal regulations. The Deepwater Port Act of 1974 is amended to promote the construction and operation of deepwater ports for importing and transporting oil while minimizing risks and promoting oil production on the outer continental shelf. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

Amends the Deepwater Port Act of 1974 by redefining Antitrust Laws and Deepwater Port. 

SEC. 4. LICENSES. The Deepwater Port Act of 1974 is amended to eliminate utilization restrictions, precondition to licensing, and conditions prescribed by the Secretary for owning, constructing, and operating a deepwater port. The Secretary will determine necessary conditions to comply with the Act and federal requirements. The Deepwater Port Act of 1974 is amended to address conditions in license conditions rather than regulations, allowing operating procedures to be in an approved manual. Restrictions on applications are eliminated, and the Secretary can make amendments, transfers, or reinstatements to licenses as needed. The Secretary can amend, transfer, or reinstate licenses as needed, as long as it complies with the Act. SEC. 5. Informational filings can be exempted upon request if deemed unnecessary by the Secretary. SEC. 6. Antitrust review section repealed. SEC. 7. Operation details. Section 7 of the Deepwater Port Act of 1974 (33 U.S.C. 1506) is repealed. Section 8 of the Act is amended to ensure non-discriminatory acceptance and transport of oil at deepwater ports. Marine environmental protection and navigational safety are addressed in Section 8. SEC. 8 of the Deepwater Port Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for public involvement, enforcement procedures for deepwater ports, and redesignation of clauses.
